title: PERVERTS TO ROME: PROTESTANT GENDER ROLES AND THE ABJECTION OF CATHOLICISM
summary: “Anti-Catholicism has always been the pornography of the Puritan,” noticed Richard Hofstadter in his famous essay “The Paranoid Style in American Politics” (21). This observation, made in the 1960s, draws upon centuries-old tradition of casting Catholics in the role of sexual perverts, not only in American politics but also in British politics and culture. Through the study of anti-Catholic Victorian writing we can analyse the particular crux embodied in Hofstadter's pithy remark: a mixture of moral superiority combined with prurient enjoyment of the described practices it purports to condemn. This part of my study is dedicated to the Victorian novel and its depictions of Catholic sexuality, which, as the novelists often suggested, was either stifled and warped or rampant, but either way it transgressed the boundaries delineated by the Protestant family ideal. It also discusses Victorian gender roles and the ways in which Catholicism was allegedly undermining them.

title: Bored to Death: Violence and Narrative Indifference in Roberto Bolaño's _2666_
Viennese Actionism: Actionists and the abject citizen
summary: For Viennese Actionism, contemplations of the intimacy of the self and the ego were carried out mostly on an individual basis, each working with different tactics for conducting their introspective works. While  occasionally collaborating for a few performances throughout the decade, remaining in a loosely formed group, their inclinations towards art-making, their determinations, and end-results were all very different—though they shared this relentless drive to make suffering visible through abjection. This paper seeks to come to an understanding of abjection in its conception as a defense mechanism of the ego against the perceived threat of the other, and the abject as that which transgresses these borders between self and other. A selection of the performance works of the Viennese Actionists, particularly those of Hermann Nitsch and Günter Brus, will be considered against these conceptions in their aesthetic, political, and psychological dimensions.

title: Stigma Stains: The Somaesthetics of Institutional Abjection, The Somaesthetics of Vulnerability, University of South Florida, Boca Raton, 28-29 January 2016
summary:
With its beautiful gardens, highly aesthetised yet functional architecture, enviable facilities, and the exceptionally rich occupational content, Bethlem Royal Hospital is the epitome of applied (‘ethical’) aesthetics in spatial, performative and relational terms. The politics of egalitarianism and the respect for differential presence are inscribed in all hospital regulations, daily routines, and the individually tailored approach to psychiatric care. And yet, this (utopian) construct is corroded by greasy fingerprints on the glass that separates nursing stations from wards, which, despite regular cleaning, act as a reminder of the time spent waiting for help or attention, by ubiquitous coffee stains which act a visible reminder of the patients’ impaired functions caused by the medication they are taking, by coagulated chewing gum on walls, in plant pots, under tables and under chairs, by the cuts in armchairs and sofas and the bruises on patients’ faces, necks and arms, which are the remnants of the more violent attacks. 

Combining Nagatomo’s notion of the body as an actional-humoural process inseparable from the environment, Kristeva’s abjectness as sub-/ob-ject-ness in exile, and Rozin’s theory of core disgust – this paper queries the relationship between applied aesthetics, politicised sociality, and (covert) stigmatisation. It argues that stigmatisation occurs behind the scenes, in looped somaesthetic processes as a byproduct of sensorial, behavioural and environmental ugliness. In acknowledging this paradox, the paper articulates the relationship between the (vulnerable) somatic body and the vulnerability of the neoliberal institutions of care.

title: MLA 2017 Proposed Special Session: The State of Abjection
From Girl Power to Independence: Violating Borders with the Abject in Alternative Narratives of "Little Red Riding Hood"
summary:
The folktale Little Red Riding Hood (LRRH) is part of Western collective consciousness owing to its long traditions and ability to constantly renew itself in narrative media. Contemporary scholars have interpreted the tale in terms of intertextuality and patriarchal ideology. With representation as a female agent in phallocentric economy, the female character in contemporary, alternative narratives of LRRH gains agency through abject and intertextual practices. In the narratives, I explore how the maternal abject, as a site of violence, subversive power and female initiation, shapes the gender and sexual identity of the young girl. In this context, the multimodal narratives also promote a female discourse of maternity, which is unrepresented in Western tradition. In the multimodal analysis that encompasses both verbal and visual stories from, for instance, Margaret Atwood, Angela Carter, Paula Rego and Kiki Smith, theories on the abject and intertextuality by Julia Kristeva are applied. Multimodal narratology, as a method, is employed to cross the borders between the narrative modalities. Both intertextual and abject phenomena are essential for renewal, growth and creative practices to take place since they cause a relapse into the semiotic center. In a violent and chaotic manner, they break communication and linear time, negotiate dominant social structures as well as transgress cultural frontiers and taboos.  In the alternative stories, the female child is portrayed as brave, independent and clever, which deviates from the stereotypical image of the passive and gentle woman. The repressed mother-child bond is clearly exhibited through the embodiments of both the initiation and the abject processes into female adulthood and sexuality, but simultaneously it departs from heteronormative traditions of motherhood. Thus, by abject and intertextual means (from different traditions of LRRH and feminist criticism), the storytellers reshape the masculine canon of the tale.
 
KEYWORDS: Little Red Riding Hood, the abject, the maternal abject, intertextuality, multimodality, fairytale

title: The Abject Heterotopia: Le città invisibili and junkspace
summary:
This article explores and compares the spaces of abjection in Calvino's Le città invisibili and the 'Junkspace' of contemporary cities as theorised by the architect Koolhaas. Depicted as being simultaneously devastating, scatalogical as well as exhilarating and aesthetical, abject space is revealed to be paradoxical and disturbing, a formlessness that puts place and identity into suspense. Here, Foucault's notion of heteropia serves as a perspective from which the nature of this abject space can be better understood. The characteristics of heteropia—such as heterogeneity, disorientation, fragmentation—are reflected in both the fictional space of Le città invisibili and the concretely-lived space of Koolhaasian architecture. But in addition, the abject heteropias in Calvino and Koolhaas rethink and challenge the Foucauldian heteropia, for they break down Foucault oppositions between heteropia and utopia, offer greater critical potentiality and even utopian implications. 

Keywords: abject, heterotopia, Calvino, città invisibili, Junkspace, Koolhaas, Foucault, comparative literature

In this essay, I argue that film is a spatial and corporeal form of representation that partakes in the construction and organisation of urban space. In that respect, the focus on characters that are usually excluded from dominant representations of the cityscape offers a subversive renegotiation of common representations of the city. In my analysis of Lenny Abrahamson’s film Adam & Paul, I will demonstrate how the film challenges common cinematic constructions of Dublin as a progressive city during the economically successful Celtic Tiger years by focussing on two homeless protagonists and their abject bodily presence in the cityscape.

title: 'We are here to speak the unspeakable: voicing abjection in Raj Kamal Jha's Fireproof
summary: This article considers Raj Kamal Jha’s Fireproof (2007), a novel that received an immediate flurry of attention in newspaper reviews but has eluded critical attention since. The article argues that Jha’s novel, set in Gujarat in the wake of the 2002 communal violence, mobilizes tropes of abjection to a number of ends, using them explicitly to convey personal disgust and self-differentiation and analogously to suggest the political processes of national abjection evident in contemporary India. It then goes on to complicate the way that abjection is presented not only as a dangerous political weapon, but also as a critically productive fictional tool for ensuring that characters are understood in bodily terms, rather than as symbols of religious affiliation. It contends that by portraying characters as abject Jha at once indicates their subalternity and opens up a space to critique the violence of silencing, thereby offering a new way of representing voices locked out of hegemonic discourse. Using Jha’s novel as a fictional example, this article offers new ways into thinking through the associated concerns of postcolonial studies, subalternity, national identification and abjection.

title: Narrative Economies of Sociality, Disgust and Abjection in Sophocles’ Philoctetes
Julia Kristeva and Hanif Kureishi: Abjection and  "Something to tell you"
summary:
The following paper aims at a psychoanalytic study of Hanif Kureishi's novel, "Something To Tell You", that appeared in 2008, and was expected to be in the same line of creative production as "My Beautiful Laundrette", and "The Buddha of Suburbia". Kureishi had already explicated the midlife crisis of characters who have all had to struggle in life in their own way. Issues of sexuality, gay/lesbianism, religion, immigration and decadence have had a relentlessly explicit portrayal in the previous novels and have made Kureishi famous for his realistic style. But what distinguishes Something To Tell You from his previous works is that there is a note of optimism in the end, a revival of love, and a sense of family and fatherhood- not based on religious teachings or moral values, but on the grounds of the characteristic need of a human being to be not finished with love when he reaches an age when he is "no longer young, and not yet old". [1] 

Kureishi tells the story of many 'families' torn apart by desire for individuality, and he takes the risk of being criticized for having made his side-characters as interesting and as complicated as the protagonist. Kureishi has to show Jamal, the main character and a Freudian psychoanalyst, in relation to other characters and has to make an attempt at depicting the life of several people in relation to one other to confirm the inner solitude of man. The novel is narrated like a session of psychoanalysis through free association.

title: 'Confronting the Abject Maternal Other in Rudyard Kipling’s "The Brushwood Boy"’
summary:
Written in 1895 and collected in The Day’s Work (1898), ‘The Brushwood Boy’ is stuffed with disturbing and surreal dream imagery. Travelling through a menacing dream landscape the ‘Brushwood Boy’, George Cottar is inexorably drawn toward a dilapidated house wherein resides the monstrously feminine ‘Sick Thing’, the corporeal manifestation of the Other whose gaze threatens annihilation. In this womb-like room that is reached through a labyrinthine network of passages, the boy meets the object of his desire, his horror, the maternal figure around which rages the melancholy of separation. Ambivalence of subject positioning, vacillation between desire and revulsion, fusion and fragmentation remain dark threads woven into the fabric of ‘The Brushwood Boy’. Sliding beneath the language of the text reveals a heterogeneous obliquity through which swirl discomfort, unease and anxiety. As Julia Kristeva in Powers of Horror argues, the subject that is carved out of the lines of demarcation sees its Other as abject. Thus in textual moments where Kipling’s ‘I’ loses or seeks itself does abjection announce itself in the heterogeneous flux of self/Other.  
My intention in this paper is to examine the ways in which ‘The Brushwood Boy’ reveals the terrifying consequences of an enforced separation from the mOther. Confronting the ‘Sick Thing’ is a marker of the process of separation from the archaic mother, the giver of demands, the manifestation of gratification thus far, of which castration signifies the end. Desire, as Lacan in Seminar XVII reminds us, once satiated in the realm of the imaginary, narcissistic in expression, now resides in the paternal function or the Name-of-the-Father that demands submission absolute. It is in ‘The Brushwood Boy’ that we are confronted with Kipling’s Other in the guise of the malignant ‘Sick Thing’; the separation from which is at the heart of the upheaval, change and chaos that tore him from his homeland, his childhood, his pre-linguistic realm and forced him to stand petrified at the edge of the abyss; alone, save for the unnameable, unspeakable anguish buried deep in his desire for his perpetually unreachable mOther.
